   • Because the look-back is short, sustained closes back under 63.9 $ would quickly negate the embryonic bullish tilt.

   • The medium-term average is still edging lower (-0.34 $/week over the last month).

   • A decisive daily close > 66 $ would complete a “close-above-50-SMA” filter and convert the 50-day into support.  

3. 200-day SMA (68.40 $)  
   • Long-term trend anchor remains negative; price is 6 % below it.

   • Statistically, upside follow-through probability improves markedly only after the tape spends ≥10 sessions north of the 200-day; we are not close to that threshold yet.

   • The 12/26-EMA spread just turned positive for the first time since mid-August—confirming the price/EMA crossover noted above.  
   • The fast line is only +0.06 over the signal, so any downtick in price momentum will flatten or reverse the histogram quickly.

1. Geopolitical Events Drive Short-Term Volatility and Bullish Moves
- On November 14, a significant Ukrainian drone attack damaged an oil depot at Novorossiysk, a major Russian export hub. This act immediately led to a surge in Brent crude prices by over 2%, reflecting heightened supply risk from a major oil producer. The incident underscores the vulnerability of global oil supply chains to geopolitical disruptions, especially in the ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict.
- Additionally, the US and EU imposed new rounds of sanctions (effective Nov 21) on Russian oil companies (notably Rosneft and Lukoil). These policies are expected to reduce Russian export capacity, further tightening the global oil supply and lending additional support to prices.

2. OPEC+ Maintains a Cautious Production Strategy
- OPEC+ announced a modest production increase for December 2025 but simultaneously signaled a pause in further quota hikes for early 2026. This reflects the group's careful balancing act: managing prices and market fundamentals while preventing a significant oversupply that could spark another price collapse.
- Analysts suggest this stance, in the wake of new sanctions, supports the market by restricting additional barrels.

- Morgan Stanley recently raised their Brent crude forecast for H1 2026 from $57.5 to $60 per barrel, citing the OPEC+ pause and Russia-related supply risk as primary drivers. This upgrade signals growing institutional confidence in a firmer price floor—provided geopolitical tension and production discipline persist.
- However, the forward outlook is not universally bullish. As recently as August, Goldman Sachs projected Brent crude would fall to the low $50s by late 2026, citing persistent supply growth outpacing demand. While not immediate, these projections serve as caution for medium-term traders.

4. Demand Concerns and Supply Dynamics Temper Bullish Momentum
- Concurrent with geopolitical bullishness, there is mounting evidence of sluggish oil demand growth. Major importers—especially China—are facing slower consumption increases due to sluggish economic recovery and structural shifts. Non-OPEC+ supply growth (notably from US shale and Brazil) also continues to present downside risk, with analysts warning of a global oversupply scenario going into 2026.
- As a result, while front-month contracts respond to near-term supply threats, back months see muted price gains, reflecting skepticism about sustained tightness.

Summary and Outlook
- The Brent crude market is oscillating between acute, short-term bullish factors (Russia-Ukraine risks, new sanctions, OPEC+ caution) and countervailing medium-term bearish influences (demand disappointment, robust non-OPEC supply). Bull’s best points  
• Brent is still the world’s reference barrel; 70 % of global crude contracts clear off it – that structural demand does not disappear overnight.  
• Prompt market is tightening now: front-month vs. 2-month backwardation doubled to ~$0.47 last week and European gasoline / heating-oil cracks popped 12 – 15 %. Those two things almost never happen in an oversupplied market.  
• Volatility (ATR) has compressed to multi-year lows; historically that precedes a $5–$10 range break within 4–6 weeks. Net spec positioning is record short – the classic pain-trade set-up.  
• Early momentum turn: price reclaimed 10-day EMA, MACD crossed up; a close above ~$66 drags in CTAs and risk-parity money.  
• Russian export risk + OPEC+ pause keeps a floor under prices; SPR is low, so swing-supply cushion is thin.

Bear’s best points  
• Every major agency (IEA, EIA, IMF) models oversupply into 2026; consensus price forecasts are being marked DOWN, not up.  
• North-Sea producers hedge every bounce, repeatedly capping rallies at the 50-day SMA ($65–$66).  
• Liquidity and open interest in deferred Brent are shrinking as funds migrate to WTI, lowering roll-yield and raising slippage risk.  
• Recent spike in cracks/backwardation could be seasonal or outage-driven; U.S. and European crude inventories have actually risen in the last reporting weeks.  
• Brent is still below the 50- and 200-day SMAs; RSI is sub-50. “Breakouts” from this posture frequently fail.

MY CALL – BUY (TACTICAL)  
I’m siding with the bulls, but only tactically – we want to rent the upside, not marry it.

Why  
1. Risk-reward is asymmetric. We can define downside at the well-defended $60 floor (~5 %) while upside to the first real resistance band ($68–$70) is 8-12 %.  
2. The combination of widening backwardation + strengthening cracks is the market’s way of saying “physical tightness is here now,” not next year’s model run. I care more about what barrels and refiners are doing today than a spreadsheet two quarters out.  
3. Positioning is heavily one-sided (record net shorts). When fundamentals start to lean the other way at the same moment, squeezes happen fast and violent.  
4. Our past mistake in similar set-ups was being frozen by the long-term bear narrative and missing 2020-Q4 and 2022-Q2 upside bursts. We learned: respect the near-term tape and the physical curve even when macro pundits are gloomy.

THE INVESTMENT PLAN

Position sizing & vehicle

• Options kicker: Buy 2-month $65 calls, sell $72 calls for a $1.10 net debit; max payoff $6.  

Allocation

Tactical milestones & adds  
• Add ½ unit on a daily settle above $66.00 (crosses 50-day SMA, triggers systematic flows).  
• Trail stop to break-even once $67 trades intraday.  
• First profit-take zone $68.50–$70 (front-month high and 200-day SMA cluster). Scale out 70 % there; leave runner with stop $65.

Hedge / exit logic  
• Immediate exit if front-month/second-month spread collapses below +$0.15 (tightness narrative invalidated).  
• Exit if RSI rolls over and closes <45 while price <10-day EMA – momentum failure signal.

Contingency  
If the market instead rolls over and closes sub-$60, flip bias to neutral-bearish and look to sell rallies into $62–$63 with tight stops; no ego, just the plan.

Execution notes  
• Work passive limits in Asian hours where Brent depth is better; avoid chasing NYMEX open air-pockets.  
• Monitor tanker-rate dashboards and Nordics load-outs daily – any sign of export surge nullifies the long thesis fast.

Review cadence  
• Daily stop-check, weekly thesis review versus inventory, time-spread, crack data.  
• Hard P&L review after first ATR expansion (>1.2), win or lose.

Bottom line  
We’re putting on a controlled, high-conviction tactical long. The downside is boxed, the curve and positioning say the squeeze potential is real, and we have a clear trigger to bail if the tape disproves us. That’s the disciplined way to capture the upside while respecting the bear’s longer-term warnings.
